Fields.DialogueText: Birts, I'm alarmed to tell you - a thief walks amongst us.
Blimey. That's unfortunate.
Worse yet, you seem to be the first victim.
What?!
The thief has absconded with a button from your overcoat, and clearly with no consideration for your dignity or bearing.
Is that all? I'll see to its replacement, Captain.
Careful, Birtwistle. The uniform of an officer must be taken seriously. Its perfection should speak of an unassailable competence, with subtle undertones of menace.
Menace, Captain?
Naturally. Does my bearing not menace you?
Well, no, Captain.
No?
I... I don't believe so.
Are you quite certain?
Well, I could see how...
There! You see? My uniform has menaced you into a state of crippling self-doubt.

Fields.MenuText: Gather yourself and report to the bridge. Our helmsman must be watched carefully, or we'll steam in circles.
Scour the ship for a suitable button. Don't show yourself until your uniform is in order.
I'm kidding, but you'll want to get that button replaced on shore leave.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, Captain. I'll see to it.
Aye, Captain. My search is underway.
You are too much, Captain.
*ALARM*
Morganas! Let's do our jobs.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, do you still terrorize Birtie about his uniform?

Fields.MenuText: Yes. Don't look at me like that - it's for his own good.
Terrorizing? That's a bit dramatic, don't you think?
I mentor him, instructing him on the proper way to wear his uniform.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh really? And how is that?
More like accurate, I would say.
Ah, so you did not berate him about a button?
Adversity builds fortitude, Paris. I'm doing him a favor.
Oui, well, just don't go too far.
Too far? That hardly seems possible.
Too far is not only possible - it's your favorite port of call.
Now, Paris, I know how best to treat my crew. Do not instruct me.
Oh, Capitaine, you're very intimidante.
It's the uniform! Too bad Birts isn't here - I was just explaining this to him.
You know, a superior of mine once set me on quest to find his lost ring. I scoured the bilge wells for weeks. All I found was a staph infection. There was no ring, you see?
So your defense is that you're only perpetuating a cycle of abuse.
Why, when you say it like that, it sounds bad.
How curious. Speaking of bilge, a Morgana approaches.
@BATTLE
Paris, it feels like the Captain always finds something wrong with my uniform. I can't win.
Perhaps the Capitaine knocks you down because you're the officer with the most potential.
Do you really think so?
Does the Capitaine treat any other officers this way?
No, it's quite unfair.
Unfair? Why, Birtie, it is special treatment.
Special treatment?
A privilege. You should be thankful.
Thankful?!
Oui. The Capitaine singles you out because he sees a star ready to ascend.
Do you really think so?
Non, I know so.
It was right in front of me, and I just couldn't see it.
Similar to your uniform. A Morgana approaches. This will have to wait.
@BATTLE
Several Morganas are approaching.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Paris, you mentioned your sister Jean Bart a while back, and I know France came to an unhappy end. What about Courbet? Is she a Belle? Are you close?
Oui, she's awoken. As for close... when we have the chance. We used to talk for hours. I'd make us petits beurres, and we'd drink and be silly.
She was always the clumsiest, you know. When I heard she'd struck a rock in Quiberon Bay my heart leapt out of my chest with worry, but I was hardly surprised.
You got the grace in the family?
Some would say. Yet France named us Courbet class battleships.
Jealous?
Don't be ridiculous. France named me after its heart, but Courbet cut a nice figure.
And Jean Bart?
Jean. She is fierce, you know? I remember when she cut off and sank the cruiser Zenta. She's always been like that. Leap first, look second.
The Huns were scared of her after that. They didn't dare her directly, so they sent submarines. Did I tell you about the wine lost when U-12...
Yes, Paris.
Cowards. U-12 hit a mine and sank the next year. The ocean does not forget.
Anyway, we limped back to Malta and they patched her up. She was never the same after that. Did you know, everyone wanted to crew the anti-submarine ships to avenge her.
I heard she had a crew mutiny.
Oui, Admiral Amet saw to that. It was not Jean's fault. The crew wanted her home. She needed to rest and heal. And yes, they had sympathy for the Bolsheviks.
You were refitted but she was not.
Yes, she needed many repairs and her name had been dragged through the mud. In the end they took even that. Now they call her Océan - but still, she is Jean.
I'm sorry. I didn't know.
Such is life.
Captain. How do you like my jacket? I purchased it from Le Bon Marché, and had a tailor alter it to fit me precisely.
Yes, well. It's elegant, of course - but don't you think it a bit extravagant?
No. You find it... extravagant?!
Birts, you're an officer, not a king. You want the crew's respect, but they must still find you approachable.
They will not approach this jacket?
Heavens, no! *That* is a jacket of kings. Would you walk right up to King George for a chat?
No, of course not...
There you have it.
I certainly don't think so.
Curious, then, that he sold you a pair of socks of two different colors.
Captain, they're both black, see?
If only, Berts. The left is midnight, the right a faded shade of ebony. Your tailor should take more care with his inventory.
They look the same to me!
Well, then, there's your problem. I suggest you enlist a second to guide your sock selections in the future.
Hmm, I will take measures.
See that you do. Also, Birts?
Yes, Captain?
The ascot is a nice touch. Mustard, yes?
Your eye for colour is remarkable.
*ALARM*
General quarters!
@BATTLE
Hm. Is your tailor colorblind?
Ah, Paris, good fortune to run into you. I need a favor.
Bon soir. What is it?
Yes, well, um. Could I trouble you to help me match my socks?
Match socks? Do you tell me, our executive officier cannot match his socks?
I used to think so. Please, Paris, it's important.
Fine, but let's make this quick. Birtie, these socks are all black!
Oh, dear - you have it too? I hope it isn't contagious.
Birtie, be clear. What on earth do you speak of?
Well, you see, I thought they matched, but the Captain caught my error.
You know, all the emphasis on uniform surprised me at first, but all part of my elevation, eh, Paris?
Let us hope. Is that ascot new?
Yes, do you like it?
It has panache. Tell me, naval matters aside, what is something you excel at?
Well, I don't lose too many hands at poker.
Intéressant. Birtwistle, mon ami, I believe it is time for you to show you've learned the lesson the Capitaine is trying to teach.
Um... have I, though?
I will see to it. Shake any rust from your hand at the card table. We shall have a game soon.
Now focus, Birtie - a Morgana approaches.
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Paris.
Capitaine. Your visit is timely. Trouble is afoot.
What's happened?
Today I overheard a midshipman talking about playing poker with Birtie. He said he won a fortune.
Cards are a good way for the crew to blow off steam - I wouldn't worry.
Oui, but only yesterday, a mate was saying she too beat Birtie handily.
You think he has a gambling problem?
He certainly seems to be losing a lot of money.

Fields.MenuText: Then I'll order him to quit.
In that case, I will confiscate his money until we reach port.
I'll inform the crew he's under special restriction from playing.

Fields.DialogueText: But would that be enough to stop a compulsive gambler?
I suspect he would play on credit.
GIven his rank, that might create a rift between him and the crew.
I think there is a better way, Capitaine. Play him yourself. Up the ante so he really sees the harm he is doing to himself.
Paris, I can't take money from my officers.
Money is only one kind of wager. How about the loser does the winner's laundry for a month?
Well, if you think it would help. I will arrange a game.
Excellent. Now ready the crew, Capitaine - Morganas approach.
Let's deal with these jokers.
@BATTLE
Is that laundry you're carrying, Capitaine? I thought you were going to play Birtie.

Fields.MenuText: My pants are about all I have left after that game.
Oh, I played. Although, it may be more accurate to say I got played.
Don't play coy with me, Paris, you know what happened.

Fields.DialogueText: He took your money, too? What happened to the friendly wager?
You lost, Capitaine? You should have told me you were bad at cards.
You didn't tell me you are bad at cards. This is hardly my fault.
I played my hand well enough. Birts just turns out to be preternaturally good at bluffing. It's almost an honor to have been fleeced.
You've been so generous sharing your knowledge with the crew. Perhaps this is a sign you need to save time for self-improvement.
Indeed?
Yes, I'd wager it would improve your fortunes.
Oh, so you gamble too?
I only play games I know I will win. Is that gambling?
No, that is predation.
Do you think me un vautour, Capitaine?
A vulture? No. More like an owl. They hear everything, use stealth to hunt, and their prey never sees them coming.
I thought because they are cute and care for their nest.
Your laundry will have to wait for the end of the impending battle.
Then let's focus your talons outward.
Where else?
@BATTLE
You're not still mad at me, are you?
Why would I be mad? Did you do something wrong?
I think not.
Paris, a good captain doesn't like to lose.
You're doing it again.
Doing what?
Speaking as Capitaine Preachy. Come, put down le chapeau du capitaine and relax.

Fields.MenuText: These are serious times, Paris.
Again you challenge my sartorial instincts. Seriously, I'm very fond of this hat.
I'll relax when the war is over.

Fields.DialogueText: Non, there are serious moments, and in between them a great deal of time. You must stop trying to control everything before you go mad.
Capitaine, if you hope to use humor to avoid a serious topic, you should at least try harder to be funny. Non?
Then you will not be making the most of the time until then. There is only so much you can control, and you do yourself no favors when you refuse to accept the fact.
Perhaps.
You don't have to take my word for it. Listen. The ocean, she speaks to you.
Yes, I hear her now.
Bien. What does she say?
The ocean says "She is mad! Swim away while you still can!"
Ah, she wants you for herself. I am the only land around here - you would certainly drown otherwise.
I feel like I'm always drowning.
Then it is good that I am always floating.
Morganas approach, Capitaine!
Then let's sink them together.
@BATTLE
Paris, have you ever wished you were a carrier?
Heavens, no. Can you imagine? Planes launching and landing all hours of the night, oil spilling on the deck...
*shudder*
You're happy being a battleship, then?
Of course. We are the best.
Well, Béarn certainly tells a different story.
Have you heard a mother tell her children she loves them all the same?
Sure.
They lie to spare their children's feelings.
So France loves you best?
Was that a question, or do you observe the fact? I was the flagship of Admiral Augustin Boué de Lapeyrère.
Yes, but all ships in the fleet play an important role.
Naturally. Is a chauffeur not important? But does the crowd look at the chauffeur or the passenger who steps out?
We sometimes escort carriers - doesn't that make us the chauffeur?
You are not usually so dense. We escort the disabled because we are chivalrous.
Shall I tell Béarn she is disabled?
Why not? What will she do, fly a plane at us? Lumber after us like an elephant?
So a destroyer, then, is like...
A little sister. You know, follows you everywhere you go. Occasionally mildly useful but usually just gets in the way. Wishes she had your big guns but, alas, is a tiny nuisance.
I really had no idea.
Don't hate me because I'm beautiful. Now, I will demonstrate our superiority. Morganas dare trouble us.
@BATTLE
Paris, your passion for food is admirable.
Merci.
I wonder if you've noticed, though, that there is time between meals. Hours, in fact.
Do you speak of meal preparation? Perhaps you refer to meal planning?
No, I...
Oh, you mean cleanup.
Actually...
Then there is stocking the galley. Reordering the galley. Reinventing the galley. It's a wonder I find time for our conversations.
Yes, well, I mean to suggest you might enjoy the time between meals were you to broaden your horizons.
I see the horizon quite clearly, Capitaine.
No, I mean you should try some other hobbies.
Perhaps cake-making?
I was thinking one that doesn't involve food. Maybe painting?
Oui, that is a good idea. Inspiration for recipes can come from many sources.
Mon dieu. A Morgana is near.
Well, doesn't that take the cake?
Non, no one takes my cake.
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Capitaine. I've completed my first painting.
Fantastic! Let's see it.
Voila!
What a beautiful whale!
Whale? It's not a whale, it is the ship!
Obviously, Paris, I speak of the whale spouting near the horizon.
I do not see it.
Yes, submerged now. Too bad you missed it.
Would you like my painting for your quarters?

Fields.MenuText: Oh, really, I couldn't. Were the crew to see me with fine art, they might think me extravagant.
You're too generous. I will hang it with pride.
It's your first painting, Paris. You should keep it for posterity.

Fields.DialogueText: That seems unlikely to me, Capitaine.
Non, a token of appreciation for your service.
Oh, is that tradition?
*ALARM*
What now?
@BATTLE
'Allo, Captain. Fancy a game tonight?
No, thank you.
Oh, come now, I'll give you double or nothing.
I'll stick to nothing. Here's your laundry.
Oh. Is this how you fold your laundry?
Yes. Is there a problem?
Just seems a bit fast and loose, is all. You're usually more... exacting in your work.
Perhaps I make a better captain than a chambermaid.
We should all be thankful for that.
Too much, Birtwistle.
Really, Captain? But...
Keep in mind you are still speaking to a superior officer.
Outside the poker room, anyways.
Birtwistle.
Right. My apologies, Captain. I meant no disrespect.

Fields.MenuText: See. To. Your. Post.
Perhaps you'd like to volunteer for our man overboard drill?
Just take it down a notch.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, Captain.
No, Captain, certainly not.
Aye, Captain. Sorry, I forget my place.
*ALARM*
To the bridge!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, the crew laugh at my paintings. Why did you not tell me they are terrible?
Because, Paris, I see only great potential. You've just started. Don't be discouraged.
They're terrible. I will never paint again.
Paris, how do you suppose Monet became Monet? Do you think Claude just decided to paint, sat down, and created "Impression, soleil levant?"
Non.
Of course not. His first painting was surely terrible. If he listened to his critics and quit, what would've happened?
We would not have his beautiful paintings.
Indeed. Don't rob the world of the beauty still in you. Today, you are a blurred lens. Practice will work smooth the imperfections until everyone sees your heart clearly.
I hope you are right... but I'm afraid.
Afraid of what?
That I have no talent, that I will never be good.
How do you feel when you paint?
Quiet. Content.
Then let the act be a gift to yourself, for yourself, and don't worry about what anyone else thinks.
Okay, I will try. But please, always tell me the truth.

Fields.MenuText: Even when the truth hurts?
I will, but you must agree to do the same.
It would hurt me too much to cause you more pain.

Fields.DialogueText: Especially then.
It is a pact, then.
I did not think you so selfish.
I wouldn't let a friend talk herself out of a calming pastime.
Merci. Honestly, I am fond of you also. But you must now be the Capitaine and I the Belle, for the Morganas have spotted us.
@BATTLE
Where are you off to in such a hurry?
My cabin. This rain is insufferable.
Yes, you really don't like to be wet, do you?
Who would?
Your friend the ocean, I suppose.
Like all friends, she has her flaws.
Careful, she might hear you.
True. We do not want to upset her.
You're shivering. Here, take my raincoat. I'll walk you.
Merci, Capitaine. Birtie seems to be enjoying his victory.
Too much, I'd say.
Come, how often does he get to trump his great Capitaine?
Not often, to be sure.
Does your ego bruise so easily?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, rub it in, please.
Inside my armor lies a gooey center.
Don't hurt my feelings.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine! You are most inappropriate.
You are a cream puff, then?
Ah. So fragile!
It's just part of my charm.
You have charm?
Is it insult-the-captain day?
Non, that is next week. Some days you are like a child.
Which days?
The ones which end with "Y."
Too much, Paris.
You're too much. Now, pull yourself together - we have an uninvited guest.
@BATTLE
That was *not* what I... You know what? Never mind.
I took your advice, Capitaine. I've finished another painting! What do you think?
Dancing pigs? How... fanciful.
It's a sunset. I am a hopeless failure.
Paris! What did we talk about?
Oui, I know. It is the journey and not the destination. Still, the journey feels like rough seas.
Well, you sail those easily enough, so navigate these waters too.
All right, Capitaine. I think I will go eat my feelings in the galley.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, cheer up, buttercup. It's not all so bad.
Ah. Something tells me you haven't heard what's on the menu today.
Wait! I have a fool-proof way to improve your mood!

Fields.DialogueText: Then tell me something happy.
Even food is to be no consolation? Capitaine, my life is despair.
I fear you may be underestimating the fool in this scenario...
I'll tell you a joke. Knock knock.
Who's there?
Duck!
Duck who?
Duck! Morgana artillery incoming!
Oh. My. That is... that is just terrible. Never tell me another joke.
Well, I tried.
Did you? That makes it even worse. And now the joke's on you.
Why is that?
Morganas. Seems your joke has turned into prophecy.
I should've knocked on wood.
@BATTLE
Report.
We're picking up a strange contact on M. Langevin's excellent device. Listen.
That is peculiar. Have you ever heard such a noise?
No. Now it's gone.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps a whale. We can't hide in our bunk every time the ocean hiccups.
Keep the crew alert. I have a bad feeling about this.
Call it in. Fleet should be aware there's a possible threat in the area.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe a whale, but what if it is a shark?
Aye, Captain. We'll keep our eyes peeled.
Radioman, you heard the Captain.
Captain, fleet says a convoy is in our area of operation. I'll raise them on the medium wave.
Could be a submarine, Captain.
Set an intercept course. Keep us out of sight, but position us behind the convoy. Warn the convoy to be on the lookout.
Aye, Captain.
What do you think, Paris?
Poseidon knows.
Greek gods now? What happened to your ocean?
She is underfoot, obviously. I never said she was alone.
Captain, convoy reports a possible periscope sighting!
Full speed ahead. General quarters!
@BATTLE
Paris, I've noticed most ships' turrets are configured in a hexagon - but not yours.
France has always set fashion, not followed it. You speak of what, Germans like Nassau?
For instance.
Germans are very practical. Have you seen their dresses?
What, there are no beautiful Germans?
Of course, but there are *only* beautiful French.
You didn't used to be so boastful.
We are friends, non? I promised to speak the truth. They made a postcard of Jean, did you know?
Is that so?
Oui. She wore a pink dress with flowers. Her hands were curled in front of her chest like a tyrannosaurus.
We called her Rex for weeks. She was embarrassed, but I know she liked the attention.
Sounds like someone else I know.
You? But you never seem to be embarrassed.
Not me! I meant you.
Please. I do not long for attention. I just want peace, and to be left to the galley. You know I can hardly make progress on my eclairs with this war.
It certainly is inconvenient.
Indeed. Even now, we cannot have a moment's peace. A Morgana pokes a nose into our waters.
Then let's bite it off.
@BATTLE
Paris, your post-battle meals have really pulled the crew together. I swear I can see them salivating even in the heat of combat.
Quite right. You've done a splendid job.
Merci. I'm pleased to do my part.
You've done that and more. Which is why we have a special honor to bestow upon you.
Quoi?
Paris, on behalf of the crew, I hereby award you... the Fleur de Cuisine!
Ha, well look at that! What an honor! I accept with a full heart, and gratitude for the opportunity to host such a wonderful crew. I shall keep it with me always.
We're the best-fed crew in the fleet. In fact, we may have to start controlling portions, or we'll also be the heaviest crew in the fleet.
I'm afraid I have noticed us sitting a bit lower in the water these days.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, we'd better get on top of that. Start tapering down the portion size.
These are dangerous times. As long as the crew's performance doesn't suffer, a little extra ballast won't hurt.
Well, let's unload any extraneous cargo in port. It will balance out.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll instruct the galley crew accordingly.
Generous of you, Captain. We'll keep the portions free, then.
Hmm, yes. Most of our supplies are quite necessary, but I'll look into it.
Thank you, Birts.
We will eat well tonight. Morganas are in the area and have taken an intercept course.
Yes, let's earn our supper.
@BATTLE
Multiple battleships.
Don't they look like eclairs?
Battleships? No. Paris, are you on a diet?
Perhaps. A Belle must watch her figure.
You're not going to faint, are you?
Of course not. I'm just hungry for battle. Aux armes!
Bon appetit!
@BATTLE
Still hungry?
That was only an appetizer. Now for some frites!
And there she goes. I would not want to be a potato in the galley right now.
Better them than us!
She doesn't look like a maneater.
No?
Touché.
Paris, I have to broach a delicate topic. Some of the crew are objecting to the morning sounding of La Marseillaise.
Scandaleux! We may be a combined fleet, but I am still a French battleship!
Certainly, but given your name, I don't think anyone needs to be reminded with a wakeup call.
It's not like we've taken down the Tricolore.
This is not open for discussion, Capitaine.
Your pride in your country is understandable, but must pride come before unity?
You ask too much.
To you, but some of the crew feel that because they do not fight for the French, they should not have to shuffle around awkwardly at dawn.
Is it really so bad, Capitaine?
I'm not one of the offended parties - I only present their point of view.
What of my point of view?

Fields.MenuText: Paris, I understand your patriotism, but I implore you to compromise. Can you do that for the greater good?
Paris, must I order you to do this?
Paris, I know you hear the crew talk. You know this is becoming an issue.

Fields.DialogueText: I will not submit to mob rule.
Capitaine, don't you dare!
Make the crew understand that some lines cannot be crossed.
Paris, I urge you to reconsider.
Capitaine, a Morgana approaches. Perhaps the crew would prefer not to suffer through firing my French guns, or loading French ammunition.
Maybe they can hurl their native insults to turn away the enemy.
Paris, now is not the time.
Of course, Capitaine. But what nerve!
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Paris.
I suppose you're here to order me to abandon my country.
No, Paris, I will not. Your feelings on the issue are unchanged?
I am still French, if that is what you're asking.
You know that's not what I'm asking.
La Marseillaise will endure.

Fields.MenuText: Very well. Worst-case scenario, one or two of the malcontents can be transferred to ships of their home countries.
I'm disappointed, but I respect your position.
Griping is a favorite pastime of the sailor. If not this, it would be something else.

Fields.DialogueText: While you're at it, perhaps you can request French replacements?
Thank you, Capitaine.
True. A pity they do not appreciate the blessings of serving on a French vessel.
I hope there are no hard feelings.
I understand you speak for the crew. Let us not talk of this again.
Right. On to happier things. How's your painting going?
Bien. I am working now on commission. A special piece.
Interesting. What--
Morganas, Capitaine! Another time.
@BATTLE
Now that order is restored, tell me about this special commissioned painting.
It is complete.
Congratulations! Do I get to see it?
Oui, but I'm nervous.
Come on, let's have it. Ah, it's Birts! Look at that.
I'm relieved you recognize him.
Of course. His crooked nose, the disheveled hair. Although--
Oh no! What is wrong?
His uniform seems much more orderly in the painting.
Oui. I take artistic liberties, you see.
Have you shown it to him yet?
Not yet.
Well I'm sure he'll be very pleased. Can I commission you to paint me also?
Perhaps. Will you pose for me?

Fields.MenuText: Surely by now you can paint me from memory.
Naturally. How should I pose?
Shall I lay upon a bearskin rug?

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. But it might be better to paint what I see instead of how I think of you.
Stand tall and valiant, gazing out to the horizon, master and commander. Some acting will be required on your part.
Certainly not. Once seen, some things cannot be unseen.
Touché.
It looks like our project must wait. Morganas approach.
@BATTLE
Stand with one foot slightly forward. Now put your hand on your hip.
Like this?
A bit higher. Yes, there. Now look into my eyes, with a piercing, commanding gaze.
Are you doing it?
Paris!
Oh. I mean, I joke. Oui, that is good. Very good. Now stand straight.
I *am* standing straight.
I mean... oh, tilt your shoulders back.
There, that is good. Try to relax.
How can I relax while standing ramrod straight and gazing piercingly into your soul?
I don't know, think of something pleasant.
Not that!
You're no fun at all.
Think of... think of a food you like.
You would say that.
Don't be difficult.
Captain, I... oh my.
We're painting.
Yes, well. Sorry to interrupt, but we've spotted a Morgana vessel.
Paris, why didn't you say so?
Oh, I didn't notice. I was concentrating.
This better not be the death of me. That would be a hell of a way to go.
Don't be a child.
@BATTLE
You know, Paris, I think I will miss you when this is war is over.
Oui. I'm sure you will.
I might even miss Birts.
Oui?
He may finally get his wish, you know.
He will be a capitaine?
Looks that way, heaven help us.
He will do well. He's had the best teachers, and the ocean will look after him.
For the sake of his crew, I hope so.
Oh, Capitaine!
Come now, don't cry.
I think I will miss you too.
We'll always have the ocean.
I fear I shall drown her in tears. What will you do?
Oh, I don't know. A couple weeks on land and I'll be stir crazy.
A true sailor.
My heart belongs to the ocean.
No accounting for taste.
Says the Belle who chose me as her captain.
I account perfectly well for that decision!
A woman after my own heart.
